title: Brexit will lead to return of the duty-free 'booze cruise'
text:
Brexit will lead to return of the duty-free 'booze cruise' Independent.ie Brexit will lead to the return of the "booze cruise" with ferry passengers enjoying duty-free wine and cigarettes for the first time in nearly 20 years. http://www.independent.ie/business/brexit/brexit-will-lead-to-return-of-the-dutyfree-booze-cruise-35581340.html http://www.independent.ie/incoming/article35581107.ece/646ef/AUTOCROP/h342/Boozecruise975057.jpg 
Brexit will lead to the return of the "booze cruise" with ferry passengers enjoying duty-free wine and cigarettes for the first time in nearly 20 years. 
The UK Chamber of Shipping, which represents ferry operators, claimed that duty-free will be "automatically" introduced on cross-channel ferries if Britain leaves the customs union. 
"This is just one of a huge number of opportunities that are available to Britons, and it is good that people are recognising them," said one senior UK government source. 
The Chamber is hoping that the UK will return to the system of the 1990s. 
At that time ferries were able to sell alcohol and cigarettes on board which were not liable for excise duty. 
Shops on ferries could sell individual allowances of duty-free to passengers up to a limit of one bottle of spirits (1 litre), two bottles of fortified wine (2 litres), 200 cigarettes, four litres of ordinary wine and 16 litres of beer. 
These allowances were available at airports and ferries until 1999. 
But then duty-free was abolished for travel between EU countries. 
Since then, travellers have only been able to take advantage of "tax-free" shopping, which is free of VAT. 
Guy Platten, the chief executive of the UK Chamber of Shipping, said the return of duty-free would be a "win-win" for travellers and ferry companies. 
"At this stage, it is impossible to predict exactly what Brexit will mean for duty-free, but the industry will be working with government to achieve the best possible outcome," said a spokesman for World Duty-Free, which runs duty-free shops across 19 British airports.
